Fig. 1 a, The PXRD patterns of the NC-supported Pd and Pd-Au catalysts. The reference standards of Au and Pd were shown as the vertical lines at the bottom. b, Zoomed patterns showing the shift of the (111) peak. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of a, Pd/NC, b, Pd1Au1/NC, and c, Pd1Au5/NC, accompanied by the particle size distributions. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 a,b, HRTEM images of Pd1Au1/NC and Pd1Au5/NC, and c, dark-field TEM with elemental color mapping images of Pd1Au1/NC. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The a, Pd 3d and, b, Au 4f XPS spectra of Pd/NC, Pd1Au1/NC, and Pd1Au5/NC. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 The temperature-ramping performance in BD hydrogenation on Pd/NC, Pd1Au1/NC, and Pd1Au5/NC: a, BD conversion (X BD), b, total selectivity of butenes (S butenes), and c, product selectivity at near full conversions. Reaction conditions: W cat = 50 mg, R473, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Stability performance at about 50 % conversion in BD hydrogenation on a, Pd/NC, b, Pd1Au1/NC, and c, Pd1Au5/NC. Reaction conditions: W cat = 50 mg, R473, H2:BD = 10:1, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The apparent activation energies and partial reaction orders of BD, H2, and 1-butene on Pd/NC, Pd1Au1/NC, and Pd1Au5/NC. n BD – n 1B indicates the relative adsorption strength between BD and 1-butene. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 a, BD-TPD, and b, 1B-TPD profiles on Pd/NC, Pd1Au1/NC, and Pd1Au5/NC. c, The normalized adsorption of BD and 1B based on the integration results from TPD profiles. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 a, BD conversion, and b, total selectivity of butenes, as a function of time-on-stream (TOS). c, the deactivation rate (k), and d, the porosity properties of the Pd1Au5/NC before and after used at different temperatures. Reaction conditions: W cat = 50 mg, R473, H2:BD = 10:1, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 a, BD conversion, and b, total selectivity of butenes, as a function of time-on-stream (TOS) at different H2:BD ratios. c, the Deactivation rate (k), and d, porosity properties of Pd1Au5/NC before and after use at different temperatures. Reaction conditions: W cat = 50 mg, R473, T = 343 K, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 a-c, The stability performance of Pd1Au5/NC in 1-butene hydrogenation at different temperatures: a, 303 K, b, 313 K, c, 323 K. Reaction conditions: W cat = 50 mg, R473, H2:1B = 10:1, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. d, Porosity properties of Pd1Au5/NC before and after use at different temperatures. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 a,b, Mass signals, and c, TGA profiles of the fresh (black) and used Pd1Au5/NC catalysts for BD (blue, green) and 1B (purple, red) hydrogenation. Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies, Zhejiang Normal University 1108 Gengwen Road Hangzhou 311231 China 1 These authors contributed equally. Selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene (BD) to butenes is a crucial step in purifying olefin feedstocks, yet conventional Pd catalysts often suffer from undesired over-hydrogenation to butane and rapid deactivation by coking. Here we report a series of nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-supported Pd–Au catalysts with varying Pd:Au ratios (prepared via incipient wetness impregnation) rationally designed to tune active site ensembles and electronic properties for enhanced selectivity and stability. Comprehensive characterization confirms the formation of Pd–Au alloy nanoparticles with electron transfer from Au to Pd, which weakens BD binding and facilitates 1-butene desorption. As a result, in BD hydrogenation these bimetallic catalysts show a marked improvement in performance: butene selectivity reaches ∼ 90 % (vs. ∼ 47 % on monometallic Pd/NC) and long-term stability is greatly enhanced. In particular, the Pd1Au5/NC catalyst exhibits minimal deactivation during extended operation. Kinetic and temperature-programmed desorption studies provide mechanistic insight, indicating that the Pd–Au surface adsorbs BD and 1-butene more weakly than monometallic Pd. This weaker binding facilitates 1-butene release and in turn suppresses further hydrogenation to butane and coke formation. Reaction conditions also strongly affect stability: lower reaction temperature and a low H2/BD feed ratio accelerate carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation in BD hydrogenation. In contrast, during 1-butene hydrogenation, similar coke deposition occurs without causing deactivation, underscoring a distinct deactivation pathway in the presence of BD. Overall, alloying Pd with Au on an NC support substantially enhances butene selectivity and catalyst durability, offering a viable strategy to mitigate over-hydrogenation and fouling in industrial olefin purification. Graphical Abstract PdAu nanoalloys impact the kinetics of butadiene and butenes adsorption, leading to suppressed over-hydrogenation and enhanced stability performance in butadiene hydrogenation. Keywords Butadiene hydrogenation Kinetics N-doped carbon Pd-Au alloy Stability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Olefin polymerization stands as a cornerstone of modern polymer science, underpinning the production of ubiquitous materials such as polyethylene and polypropylene. These polymers, derived primarily from ethylene and propylene, are pivotal to industries ranging from packaging to automotive manufacturing. Within this realm, the role of butadiene—a conjugated diene—has garnered significant attention, both as a comonomer in copolymer systems and as a potential impurity in olefin feedstocks. The selective hydrogenation of butadiene emerges as a critical process, enabling precise control over polymer architecture and properties, while mitigating undesired side reactions during polymerization [1–3]. Heterogeneous catalysts have emerged as the cornerstone of this transformation due to their robustness and adaptability to industrial-scale processes. These catalysts must exhibit high activity for butadiene conversion while minimizing over-hydrogenation of valuable mono-olefins (e.g., 1,3-butadiene → 1-butene or 2-butene), which could degrade feedstock utility or polymer performance [4]. Heterogeneous catalysts, including supported palladium [5–7], platinum [8–10], or nickel [11–13], are widely employed due to their robust activity. Advances in catalyst design—such as nanostructured supports and bimetallic systems—have improved selectivity and resistance to deactivation. Palladium (Pd) supported on carriers such as alumina (Al₂O₃) [14], silica (SiO₂) [15], or TiO2 [16] is widely employed due to its intrinsic ability to activate hydrogen and selectively hydrogenate dienes. However, unmodified Pd catalysts often suffer from over-hydrogenation, leading to alkane formation. To address this, Pd is frequently alloyed with secondary metals (e.g., Ag [17,18], Cu [19,20], or Au [21,22]) or doped with promoters (e.g., FeO x [23], Ni [24]) to modulate electronic and geometric properties [25]. Combining experimental catalytic testing and theoretical calculations, Yang et al. [26] found that 1:1PdCu/Al2O3 displayed both higher activity and higher total butene selectivity than the pristine Pd/Al2O3, thus breaking the commonly observed activity-selectivity trade-off. Both the electronic and geometric effects were responsible for the superior performance of the bimetallic. Building upon equilibrium models of BD hydrogenation, another recent study by Liu et al. [25] also demonstrated that PdW/Al2O3 catalyst outperforms Pd/Al2O3 in activity, selectivity, and stability. Additionally, Pd has also been doped in trace amounts to enhance the activity and stability of less-active metal catalysts such as Cu For instant, Wang et al. [27] recently reported atomically dispersed Pd-promoted Cu/TiO2 exhibiting a stable performance of 130 h time-on-stream in contrasting to the fast deactivation within 15 h of the un-promoted catalyst. While palladium- and platinum-based catalysts have dominated this field, several studies have spotlighted gold catalysts as promising alternatives, offering unique selectivity even at full conversions [28,29]. Traditionally considered catalytically inert in bulk form, gold exhibits remarkable activity when engineered as nanoparticles (NPs) or atomically dispersed sites on tailored supports, unlocking its potential for selective diene transformations. For instance, Masoud et al. [29] demonstrated a selective and stable performance of Au/SiO2 even at 473 K. Gold can preferentially adsorb and activate dienes (e.g., butadiene) over mono-olefins due to their specific π-bond interaction, thus minimizing alkane formation. Despite this progress, several hurdles remain with the gold systems. In particular, Au catalysts exhibited much lower hydrogenation activity than Pd systems; thus, much higher reaction temperatures are required on the former [30]. In addition, the deposition of carbonaceous species under reaction conditions also occurs, leading to gradual catalyst deactivation [29]. Combining the distinct strengths of Pd (high hydrogenation activity) and Au (enhanced selectivity), Pd-Au alloys have emerged as a strategic solution to optimize catalytic performance in butadiene hydrogenation [21,22,31,32]. By simply playing with the Au/Pd ratio, one can tune the hydrogenation performance [33–35]. For instance, Hugon et al.[33] found that the selective hydrogenation to 1-butene-rich mixture can be reached by doping the Au catalysts with ppm level Pd, and the activity scales with the increasing Pd contents. Using co-impregnation and H2 reduction, Liu et al. [34] prepared MIL-101(Cr)-supported bimetallic, with molar Au:Pd ratios ranging from 1:3 to 3:1. It was revealed that Au(2)Pd(1)/MIL-101(Cr) with Au: Pd = 2 showed the optimal balance between the activity and butene selectivity. Bachiller-Baeza et al. [36] prepared and tested different-shaped (tetrapods and needles) ZnO-supported Pd-Au catalysts (Au: Pd = 0.53), and found similar performances between them. Despite the different observation in the previous finding, the formation of Pd-Au alloys has been confirmed by different techniques such as TEM-EDX [34–36] mapping and CO-DRIFT [37]. The surface compositions of Pd-Au alloys might exert a significant influence on the catalytic performance. Kolli et al. [37] revealed that a higher Au: Pd ratio, beneficial for segregating Pd atoms, is crucial for selective hydrogenation performance, while Pd dimers are responsible for over-hydrogenation. In a more recent paper, van der Hoeven et al. [21] developed single-crystalline Au-core Pd-shell nanorods exhibiting 50 times higher activity than their alloyed and monometallic counterparts, while retaining high selectivity. A shell-thickness-dependent catalytic activity was revealed, suggesting that both the surface and several subsurface layers might play a crucial role in the hydrogenation. Despite the advances achieved in the Pd-Au systems for BD hydrogenation, most of the previous works have focused on balancing the activity-selectivity trade-off, while the impact on catalyst stability receives little attention. Besides, the different reaction kinetics between the alloy catalyst and the respective monometallic analogues remain largely underexplored. Nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) supports, known for improving metal dispersion and stability, offer a robust platform for anchoring bimetallic systems. For instance, our previous works reveal that regulating the N defects in NC is an elegant approach to controlling the dispersion of mono- and bimetallic species (Ir [38], Pt-Bi [39]). In this work, we synthesize Pd-Au/NC catalysts with controlled Pd: Au ratios to investigate the alloying effect on reaction kinetics and catalyst stability in BD hydrogenation. Through comprehensive characterization (PXRD, TEM, XPS, TPD) and kinetic studies, we elucidate how Au incorporation alters electronic properties, particle size, and adsorption behavior. We further correlate these structural features with catalytic performance, particularly selectivity and stability under varying reaction conditions. Our findings provide valuable insights into the design of selective hydrogenation catalysts, emphasizing the synergy between alloy formation and support interactions in optimizing activity and durability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation N-doped carbon (NC) with ca. 10 N content was prepared by pyrolysis of self-made polyaniline following the previously reported recipe [38,39]. Monometallic Pd and bimetallic Pd1Au1 and Pd1Au5 catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method with NC as the support. The Pd metal loading was fixed at 0.5 wt%. For the Pd1Au1 and Pd1Au5 catalysts, the Au content was determined based on the molar ratios of Pd to Au, which were 1:1 and 1:5, respectively. The detailed preparation procedure is as follows: Palladium chloride (0.0336 g) and an appropriate amount of chloroauric acid were separately dissolved in a 1.25 mol L⁻¹ dilute hydrochloric acid solution. The solutions were continuously stirred until complete dissolution of the solids was achieved. Then, the prepared solutions were added to 6 g of the NC support (with a mass ratio of w NC:w HCl = 1:1.1). The mixture was thoroughly stirred to ensure uniform dispersion. The impregnated support was dried in an oven at 373 K for 12 h. The dried catalyst precursor was transferred to a tube furnace, heated to 673 K under a N2 atmosphere, and then reduced under H2 flow for 3 h. Two additional Au/NC catalysts were also prepared in a similar manner with the nominal metal contents of 1 and 5 wt% for reference. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalysts were analyzed using the Quanta Chromium NT3LX-2 physical adsorption apparatus. First, 100 mg of the sample was weighed and placed in a quartz tube and degassed at 573 K for 3 h. Then the N2 adsorption-desorption curve was collected at 77 K. The catalysts were analyzed on the Quanta Chromium NT3LX-2 physical adsorber. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the total pore volume was calculated using N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of p/p 0 = 0.95. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were acquired using an X′Pert 3, PANalytical X-ray powder diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source, with a tube current of 40 mA and a tube voltage of 40 kV. Scanning from 10° to 90° 2θ at a scan rate of 0.2° min−1 was recorded. Raman spectra were acquired on a confocal laser micro Raman spectrometer (HORIBA, Lab RAM HR Evolution), using the wavelength of 532 nm, the scan time of 60 s, and the scanning wavelength of 100–2000 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis coupled with mass spectroscopy (TGA-MS) was conducted on a STA 449F5 thermogravimetric analyzer. The sample powder was weighed into an α-Al2O3 crucible and heated up to 1073 K under an air atmosphere at a ramping rate of 10 K min−1 and the MS signals of CO2 and H2O were recorded. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (15 kV, Al Kα X-ray source). The C 1s peaks were calibrated at the binding energy of 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) tests were performed on a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. After the sample was fully ground, the sample powder was dispersed in ethanol through ultrasonic treatment, and the suspension was dropped onto a copper mesh carbon film to observe the distribution, shape, and spatial placement of the metal particles. The NanoMeasurer software was adopted to count the metal particle size distributions. To ensure the accuracy of the data, the number of particles counted for each sample was no less than 120. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 chemisorbent equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a mass spectrometer (MS) to study the adsorption properties of the catalysts for butadiene and 1-butene. Taking BD-TPD as an example, about 100 mg catalyst was loaded into a U-shaped quartz tube reactor, pretreated with He at 393 K for 30 min, then the sample was heated to 473 K (10 K min−1), 10 H2/Ar was introduced for in situ reduction for 1 h, and then cooled to 323 K under helium. Then 2 vol% BD/N2 (30 cm3 min−1) was introduced into the sample for 1 h to ensure saturated adsorption. The gas flow was then switched to He and purged for 1 h to remove the BD species physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Finally, heating up to 773 K (10 K min−1) was applied for a desorption test, and the signal was recorded by both TCD and MS during this process. The experimental method of 1-butene-TPD was the same as that of BD-TPD, except that the gas used in the adsorption and desorption process was 5 vol% 1-butene/N2. 2.3 Catalytic testing The evaluation of the butadiene hydrogenation reaction was carried out on a fixed-bed micro quartz reactor (inner diameter of 6 mm, length of 40 mm) designed by ourselves in our laboratory under atmospheric pressure. Before each reaction, 20–40 target catalyst particles need to be weighed. The catalyst pellets were then loaded into the reactor and sandwiched with quartz cotton above and below. Finally, the quartz tube was placed vertically in the electric furnace, and the center of the catalyst was aligned parallel to the position of the thermocouple. Before starting the reaction, all catalysts were heated to 473 K under a nitrogen atmosphere (50 cm3 min−1) and the gas was switched to pure H2 (50 cm3 min−1) for 1 h to perform in situ reduction. After the reduction, the catalyst was cooled naturally in a N2 atmosphere. The reaction gases comprising of 2.01 vol% BD/N2, H2, and equilibrium N2 were introduced into the reactor. The typical molar ratios of H2:BD = 10–30, and the total gas flow rate (F total) was 75 cm3 min−1, corresponding to the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. The test conditions for the apparent activation energy were as follows: H2:BD = 10, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, T = 308–323 K, BD conversion (X BD) < 25 %; W cat = 50 mg, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. For determining the H2 reaction orders, the BD partial pressure was set at 0.69 %, and the H2 partial pressures were set as: P H2 = 0.012–0.069. For determining the BD reaction orders, the H2 partial pressure was set at 8.9 %, and the BD partial pressures were set as: P BD = 0.012–0.069. For the 1-butene hydrogenation reaction test, the reaction conditions were as follows: W cat = 50 mg, H2:1B = 10–30, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 90,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. For determining the 1-butene orders, the reaction conditions are: W cat = 20 mg, F total = 75 cm3 min−1, GHSV = 225,000 cm3 gcat −1 h−1, the H2 partial pressure was set at 17.53 %, and the 1B partial pressures were set as: P 1B = 0.013–0.026. Reaction products were analyzed on-line by an Agilent 7890B gas chromatography using a CEC-Al2O3 30 m × 0.53 mm × 10 μm column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The reactants and products were calibrated using standards of known concentrations. The conversion (X) and product selectivity (S) were calculated by Eqs. (1), (2), respectively, (1) X (%) = (F BD, in – F BD, out)/F BD, in × 100 (2) S i ( % ) = F i , out / ∑ j F out × 100 where F BD, in and F BD, out were the inlet and outlet BD flow rates in mol min−1, respectively, and F i, out and F j, out were the outlet flow rates of different products. i (j) = 1-butene, trans-2-butene, cis-2-butene, or butane. Good carbon balances were obtained under all the tested conditions (typically within 100 ± 2 %). 1-Butene hydrogenation was evaluated in the same equipment as for BD hydrogenation. Similar catalyst activation procedures were adopted, and 5 vol% 1B/N2 was used as the feed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the catalysts The NC-supported mono- and bi-metallic Pd catalysts with nominal Pd content of 0.5 wt% and two different Au: Pd molar ratios of 1 and 5 were derived by a wetness impregnation method, and were characterized by multiple techniques. The PXRD of Pd/NC reveals only a broad amorphous peaks associated with the NC host and no diffractions of metallic Pd ( Fig. 1), suggesting the high dispersion of the metal. On the contrary, two strong diffraction lines at 2θ = 38.1 and 44.3° can be observed for both Pd1Au1/NC and Pd1Au5/NC, which are close to the (111) and (200) facets of Au (PDF#02-1095). The amplified PXRD at 2θ = 38.1–38.5° further revealed a slight shift of the (111) facets. Altogether, these results indicated the agglomeration of Au species on NC and likely the alloying between Pd and Au, thus causing the lattice expansion. The distributions of the metal species on the catalysts were examined by TEM. While homogeneous distribution of small nanoparticles on the host can be observed for all the catalysts, the mean particle sizes were smaller for Pd/NC than for Pd1Au1/NC and Pd1Au5/NC (2.9 vs. 4.5 nm, Fig. 2). These observations were in line with the PXRD results, further confirming the agglomeration of metals upon Au modification. HRTEM analysis of the d spacing revealed the typical values of 1.9 and 2.2 Å for the two bimetallic catalysts ( Fig. 3 a,b), which might be assigned to the (200) and (111) facets, respectively, of PdAu alloys. The elemental color mapping images further confirmed the geometrical relevance between Pd and Au (Fig. 3 c–f), as well as several large Au nanoparticles. The electronic properties of the catalysts were assessed by XPS. The Pd 3d XPS spectra of all the catalysts displayed a broad envelope at 330–340 eV ( Fig. 4), owing to the contributions of Pd0 and Pd2+ species (respective positions at 335.8 and 337.3 eV). With the addition of Au, the spectra slightly shifted to lower binding energies, suggesting the increasing contribution of Pd0 were respect to Pd2+ species. Agreeing with this trend, the Au 4f also slightly shifted from 84.2 to 84.4 eV when the Au:Pd ratio was increased from 1 to 5. The consistent results, therefore, suggested the presence of strong electronic interactions between the two metals. According to the previous literature results [35], the formation of PdAu alloys would induce electron transfer from Au to Pd, which might be reasonably explained by the higher electronegativity of Au than Pd (2.54 vs. 2.20). Additionally, estimation of the surface Pd/Au ratios revealed 1.60 and 1.07 for Pd1Au1/NC, and Pd1Au5/NC, respectively. These values are much higher than the theoretical ones, suggesting likely the enrichment of Pd on the catalyst surface. Taking all the above characterizations, it can be concluded that the introduction of Au might induced the formation of PdAu alloys and enlarged the particle sizes. 3.2 Catalytic performance in BD hydrogenation To study the impact of Au addition on the performance of Pd catalysts, all the derived catalysts were evaluated in BD hydrogenation under the typical reaction conditions in a temperature ramping-up mode ( Fig. 5 a,b). Full BD conversion was achieved at a lower temperature of 353 K on Pd/NC, while it was delayed to around 373 K for the bimetallic catalysts, thus indicating the reduced hydrogenation activity owing to the alloying effect. Despite the lower activity, the total selectivity of butenes (S butenes) was significantly improved on the alloyed catalysts. Namely, the S butenes at approaching full BD conversions were enhanced to 86.5–90.2 % on the bimetallic catalysts as compared with only 47.1 % on Pd/NC. These results indicated that over-hydrogenation can be significantly suppressed on the alloy catalysts. Indeed, this conclusion can be further supported by examining the product distributions (Fig. 5 c). As one can see, the butane selectivity decreased dramatically from 53 % on Pd/NC to 15 % on Pd1Au1/NC, and to 10 % on Pd1Au5/NC. Noted that the Au/NC catalysts and the pure NC carrier showed basically no activity in BD hydrogenation even up to 423 K (Fig. S1). The influence of Au addition on the catalyst stability in BD hydrogenation was further studied. To this end, reaction conditions corresponding to about 50 % BD conversion were selected for the respective catalysts based on the temperature ramping results, as presented previously in Fig. 5. The 12 h time-on-stream (TOS) test showed continuous activity drop on Pd/NC, with the X BD decreasing from 44.4 % to 29.6 % ( Fig. 6 a). For Pd1Au1/NC, a fast deactivation can still be observed at the initial three hours, although thereafter the activity retained relatively more stable (Fig. 6 b). Pd1Au5/NC showed only a slight drop in X BD in the first hour (about 1.5 %) and the activity could be well maintained in the following test (Fig. 6 c). These results strongly suggest that the alloying of Pd with Au can not only suppress over-hydrogenation, but also enhance the stability performance in BD hydrogenation. 3.3 Reaction kinetics and chemisorption To understand the different catalytic performances between the Pd and PdAu catalysts in BD hydrogenation, the reaction kinetics were studied under low conversions (X BD <25 %) at 308–323 K. The apparent activation energies (E a) of the catalysts were estimated by the Arrhenius equation. It turns out that all the catalysts exhibited similar E a values between 43 and 44 kJ mol−1 (Fig. S2a). The reaction orders of H2 and BD (n H2, n BD) were also calculated by varying the partial pressure of the respective reactant while keeping the other constant. The n H2 was in a close range of 0.53–0.55 between the catalysts, while the n BD varied more largely from − 1.10 to − 1.27 (Fig. S2b,c). These kinetic data generally agreed well with the previous literature results for Pd-based catalysts [5,40]. The negative reaction orders of BD are consistent with its strong competitive adsorption on the active sites relative to H2. The almost constant H2 reaction orders between Pd and PdAu alloy catalysts might suggest that the activation of molecular H2 was not much influenced by the formation of PdAu alloy. Therefore, the kinetic analysis suggests that the reduced hydrogenation activity of the PdAu alloy likely stems from diminished BD activation propensity, which, within the Langmuir-Hinshelwood framework, may reflect weaker effective adsorption or lower coverage of BD on alloyed sites compared to pure Pd. In order to further understand the different selectivity properties among the different catalysts, the partial reaction order of an intermediate hydrogenation product, 1-butene, was also considered (n 1B, Fig. S2d). The n 1B of the two alloyed catalysts was also greatly reduced as compared with that of Pd. All these kinetics data were summarized in Fig. 7. As one can see, although both n BD and n 1B reduced upon the increasing addition of Au, the relative differences actually increased (n BD – n 1B). Therefore, this result suggested that the intermediate hydrogenation products might be more easier to desorb from the alloy catalysts, thus showing much higher selectivity to butenes. We have further performed the chemisorption performance of the different catalysts using the temperature-programmed desorption technique (TPD) with both BD and 1-butene as the probing molecules. One BD desorption peak centered at ca. 473 K can be observed for all the catalysts, while the 1B desorption occurred at a relatively lower temperature at ca. 454 K ( Fig. 8 a,b). With the increasing addition of Au, the desorption amounts of both molecules decreased, particularly for 1-butene. To more clearly present this trend, integration of the desorption peaks in the TPD profiles were performed and the normalized results, with respective to the desorption on Pd/NC as the benchmark, were displayed in Fig. 8 c. Accordingly, one can see the decreased adsorption of both BD and 1-butene with the increase of Au in the catalysts. Moreover, the decrease was more severe for 1-butene than for BD. This observation agreed well with the increased n BD – n 1B, thus further supporting the eased desorption of 1-butene from the alloy catalyst and explaining the superior selective hydrogenation performance. 3.4 Influence of key reaction parameters on catalyst stability in BD hydrogenation Since Pd1Au5/NC showed relatively stable performance than Pd/NC and Pd1Au1/NC in the above studies, it was chosen for examining the influence of key reaction parameters on the catalyst stability. Based on the temperature-ramping test, the impact of bed temperature was first examined at 343–373 K (Fig. S3). A comparison of the stability performance showed several temperature-dependent trends. Below 358 K, the conversions showed an initial rapid decrease within the first hour, accompanied with a relatively stable period in the next ten hours. On the contrary, the conversion even showed slight increase at a higher temperature of 373 K ( Fig. 9 a). Despite of the variations in conversion at below 358 K, the total selectivity of butenes (S butenes) remained essentially stable (98.4 % and 98.8 %) during the cause of evaluation, while the S butenes dropped and gradually stabilized from 89.2 % to 86.5 % at 373 K (Fig. 9 b). To better compare the stability under different temperatures, the deactivation rate (k) was defined as the drop of BD conversion per hour during TOS evaluation. Due to the different trends in conversion fluctuation, k 1 and k 2 were calculated to more accurately reflect the deactivation behaviors at different stages of TOS as shown in Fig. 9 c. In general, a higher bed temperature led to lower deactivation rates. The porosity of the fresh and used catalysts was further compared and presented in Fig. 9 d. Compared to the fresh catalyst, both the specific surface area (S BET) and the total pore volume (V total) significantly decreased after catalytic uses. Moreover, the reductions in both S BET and V total became more severe with decreasing bed temperatures. This suggests the pore blockage of Pd1Au5/NC during the hydrogenation, particularly at low temperatures. Nonetheless, it cannot be directly linked to the cause of catalyst deactivation as proofed by the test at 373 K wherein reduction in catalyst porosity did not lead to reduced conversion. The H2:BD ratio is another key reaction parameter influencing the catalytic performance. The impact on catalyst stability was assessed at the low temperature of 343 K with varying H2:BD = 10–30 (Fig. S4). At a ratio below 20, the two-stage deactivation curves were still observed, with a fast drop in conversion within the first one hour, followed by a much slower deactivation ( Fig. 10 a). In contrast, the conversion slightly increased at the very beginning and reached almost full conversion when the H2:BD ratio reached 30. Accompanied with the slight activity increase, the S butenes dropped at the first eleven hours from 89 % to 81 % (Fig. 10 b). Comparison on the deactivation rates also showed a relatively more stable performance at a higher H2:BD ratios (Fig. 10 c). Porosity analysis of the fresh and used catalysts revealed the decreased S BET and V total after the catalytic tests, and the reductions were even more severer at lower H2:BD ratios (Fig. 10 d). It can thus be concluded that a lower H2:BD ratio led to more severer blockage of catalyst pores during BD hydrogenation on Pd1Au5/NC. 3.5 1-Butene hydrogenation To further understand the stability patterns of the Pd1Au5/NC catalyst, we conducted 1-butene hydrogenation, particularly at a low H2:BD ratio of 10, and at low temperatures of 303–323 K ( Fig. 11 a–c). Despite of the low H2:BD ratio and low temperatures, an induction period was observed during these tests, and it became shorter at higher temperatures. These behaviors were very different from those observed in BD hydrogenation, wherein the conversion profiles were strongly influenced by both the temperature and H2:BD ratios. Therefore, no catalyst deactivation was observed in 1-butene hydrogenation even under the most harsh reaction conditions for BD hydrogenation, i.e., low temperature and low H2:BD ratio. Even so, comparison on the porosity of fresh and spent Pd1Au5/NC catalysts still revealed the similar trends in S BET and V total as a function of the reaction temperature for both 1B and BD hydrogenations (Fig. 11 d). It is thus interesting that although blockage of catalyst pores occurred in both reactions, the impacts on catalyst stability differed markedly. On the other hand, the product selectivity was also less influenced by TOS in 1B hydrogenation, with trans- and cis-2-butenes as the key products and formation of only a little butane. This result might hint at the high propensity of isomerization between 1-butene, and trans- and cis-2-butenes on Pd1Au5/NC instead of over-hydrogenation, which can well explain the higher selectivity of trans-2-butene in BD hydrogenation when approaching full conversions. 3.6 Coke deposition analysis To reveal the cause of pore blockages of the catalysts during BD and 1B hydrogenation, the Pd1Au5/NC catalysts before and after catalytic uses under different reaction conditions were analyzed by Raman and TGA-MS. Two distinct D and G bands between 1300 and 1700 cm−1 were observed for all the catalysts (Fig. S5). The relative band intensities of I D: I G were within very close values (1.08–1.12), thus it is impossible to clearly distinguish the different carbonaceous deposits on the catalysts. For the TGA-MS, the MS signals of CO2 showed a small releasing peak at 675 K following a major peak at ca. 923 K for all the catalysts ( Fig. 12 a), indicating the existence of at least two different types of carbon materials. Moreover, corresponding H2O signals were found at the same temperature range, except a low-temperature peak below 453 K due to hydration (Fig. 12 b). To exclude the interference of catalyst hydration, the TG profiles of all the catalysts were aligned at 453 K, as shown in Fig. 12 c. These catalyst profiles were all very similar, but a closer look into the range of 680–760 K revealed noticeable differences in the weight loss (inset in Fig. 12 c). As compared with the fresh Pd1Au5/NC, the two catalysts after BD hydrogenation showed greater weight loss than the two counterparts used in 1B hydrogenation, suggesting more severer coke depositions during BD hydrogenation. Furthermore, the catalyst used in 343 K also showed a heavier weight loss than that used in 373 K, agreeing with the faster catalyst deactivation at lower temperatures in BD hydrogenation. These results, together with the N2 sorption analysis and stability tests, pointed to the different coking propensities of the reactants. The faster deactivation rate and severe coke deposition in BD hydrogenation might suggest that higher oligomerization propensity of BD over 1B. 4 Conclusions In this work, nitrogen-doped carbon supported Pd-Au alloy catalysts with varying Pd:Au ratios were synthesized and comprehensively characterized. Structural analyses confirmed the formation of Pd–Au bimetallic nanoparticles, with increasing Au content leading to larger particle sizes and notable electronic interaction—evidenced by shifts in PXRD peaks and XPS binding energies. These observations support the successful formation of Pd–Au alloys with electron transfer from Au to Pd, which modulates the adsorption behavior of hydrocarbon species. Catalytic evaluation in butadiene hydrogenation revealed that both Pd1Au1/NC and Pd1Au5/NC significantly outperformed monometallic Pd/NC in terms of butene selectivity and catalyst stability. Notably, Pd1Au5/NC exhibited superior long-term performance with minimal deactivation. Kinetic and TPD studies uncovered a clear trend: increasing Au content weakens the adsorption of both butadiene and 1-butene, with a more pronounced effect on the latter. The difference in reaction orders and corresponding TPD desorption data establish a consistent correlation between alloy composition and surface intermediate behavior. This weakened adsorption facilitates rapid desorption of 1-butene, thereby suppressing over-hydrogenation to butane and reducing the likelihood of coke formation. Moreover, distinct structural features between Pd1Au1/NC and Pd1Au5/NC—such as particle size, alloy homogeneity, and surface composition—offer a plausible explanation for their divergent stability profiles under identical conditions. While both alloys enhance selectivity via ensemble and electronic effects, the higher Au loading in Pd1Au5/NC further contributes to reduced hydrocarbon affinity and enhanced resistance to deactivation. The influence of reaction parameters such as temperature and H2:BD ratio further emphasizes the role of hydrocarbon adsorption strength in determining catalyst stability. Coke analysis confirmed that butadiene-derived deposits are the primary cause of deactivation, while 1-butene hydrogenation does not lead to significant performance loss despite similar coke formation. This indicates a fundamental difference in surface chemistry between BD and 1-butene on Pd–Au alloys. Overall, this study demonstrates that structural modulation of Pd–Au alloys—through controlled Pd:Au ratios—systematically influences particle characteristics, surface electronic structure, and adsorption properties. These in turn govern catalytic performance and durability, providing mechanistic insight into how alloy composition determines hydrogenation selectivity and stability. Such correlations are crucial for rational design of advanced bimetallic catalysts in selective hydrogenation applications. coredata.dc:description: Selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene (BD) to butenes is a crucial step in purifying olefin feedstocks, yet conventional Pd catalysts often suffer from undesired over-hydrogenation to butane and rapid deactivation by coking. Here we report a series of nitrogen-doped carbon (NC)-supported Pd–Au catalysts with varying Pd:Au ratios (prepared via incipient wetness impregnation) rationally designed to tune active site ensembles and electronic properties for enhanced selectivity and stability. Comprehensive characterization confirms the formation of Pd–Au alloy nanoparticles with electron transfer from Au to Pd, which weakens BD binding and facilitates 1-butene desorption. As a result, in BD hydrogenation these bimetallic catalysts show a marked improvement in performance: butene selectivity reaches ∼ 90 % (vs. ∼ 47 % on monometallic Pd/NC) and long-term stability is greatly enhanced. In particular, the Pd1Au5/NC catalyst exhibits minimal deactivation during extended operation. Kinetic and temperature-programmed desorption studies provide mechanistic insight, indicating that the Pd–Au surface adsorbs BD and 1-butene more weakly than monometallic Pd. This weaker binding facilitates 1-butene release and in turn suppresses further hydrogenation to butane and coke formation. Reaction conditions also strongly affect stability: lower reaction temperature and a low H2/BD feed ratio accelerate carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation in BD hydrogenation. In contrast, during 1-butene hydrogenation, similar coke deposition occurs without causing deactivation, underscoring a distinct deactivation pathway in the presence of BD. Overall, alloying Pd with Au on an NC support substantially enhances butene selectivity and catalyst durability, offering a viable strategy to mitigate over-hydrogenation and fouling in industrial olefin purification.
